reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’m playing the game since the beginning of the early access and it has come a long way since so it’s time to do a check-up.

Pros :
- Play local solo or coop. Play online or even local coop online!
- Build your own place to survive. You will spend some time before getting a good camp. With the most recent update, you can set a camp attack and defend it from zombies waves!
- Kovac. This character is hilarious!
- Various recipes for crafting. Literally everything is used for crafting, even junk you can melt in a foundry. No leftover.
- Missions : you will go on several missions to gain xp and loot. You can increase the level of the mission for a “high risk, high reward” gameplay but you can also decrease it if you want to go on an easy way.
- Battle gameplay. Use melee weapons or guns but don’t get outrun nor outnumbered otherwise you will have a bad time. You need to aim your enemy and keep it in sight for a critical shot. The faster you can get it, the better.
- Post-apo weapons : you see that they are really made of what you used to craft them!
- Finishing moves. It feels so good !
- Flying pets!
- Season events: we got thanksgiving or christmas missions and specific loots!
- You can customize your character from the inventory at any time. (Topless character against zombies ftw!)

Cons :
- It’s still early access. Some things are unfinished but as the time goes, we have less and less missing features.
- Environnement is repetitive. It’s either swamps or city with the same look.
- Some resources are hard to find, even quest related ones.
- In order to craft/upgrade specific weapons or buildings, you will need to grind levels or farm resources.
- The hunger and thirst does not penalize you enough. Having 0% hunger/thirst penalize you in combat (You will hit like a fly and your aim will be awfully slow) but your health will remain unchanged so it cuts the “survival” a half.
- If you play in public, be prepared : you obviously have player killers, robbers and griefers. So I recommend playing with friends only for the best coop experience. (On the contrary, if you search for a “pvp” like gameplay style, go for it!)

The game is on the right path and has improved a lot since its launch so if you like zombies, crafting and survival in hostile and desolate territory, buy it, you’ll enjoy the journey. And of course, with friends. The more, the merrier! (With the notable exception of your resources.)

Early Access Review

Intro - About 	You start out as a surviver, a surviver that has been given an opportunity to be helped by another, that has a good bit of knowledge of surviving in this horrible apocalyptic wasteland that once was a beautiful world we call Earth. This strange man gives you tasks to help him help you and along the way you will find loot such as weapons, gear, armor, food and items to craft with. Set up a camp to help you store your unused items that are only weighing you down to continue forth and gather more materials to help you survive against terrifying zombies that are hoarding areas and building all for themselves. Build the best weapon to create the most devastating hits, and clear out your path to get to you objective safely.

Get to know the game > Great wasteland/broken down villages and buildings
> Crafting your own items from looting killed zombies or just things laying around
> Play the story with a friend
> Free roaming is just as fun as the story
> Different weapons and armor stats increase or decrease
> Brutal devastating hits
> Break doors down to get inside houses
> Gives a cool old school retro aspect of the year your in
> Intense sistuations

Pros & Cons ++  Pros
+ Great graphics
+ Co-op
+ Free roam
+ Customization
+ Detailed story
+ Gore
+ Easy controls
+ Realistic
+ Suspenseful
+ Controller compatible

-- Cons
- User interface is uneasy to control (learn)
- Slow at times

Summary - Non Spoiler You are a surviver that gets help from another surviver that knows a lot about how to survive and guides you through missions and quests. He teaches you how to get things done. Along the way while doing these tasks or even just free roaming, you may find loot. You can find loot just about everywhere. Find items to help you craft better weapons and armor and increase your stats to help you survive longer. You can also craft a camp to help you store away items that you don’t need right away. Items have weight and can weigh you down and make you slower. Being over encumbered and becoming slower will greatly increase your percentage of death. Zombies may seem slow but do not take them for advantage, they will come from all directions, around corners and in hordes. You must make common decisions whether or not you should just stay and fight them off so you can reach your objective or quickly run and hide it out or find a safer way. This is not, just your usual zombie game where you can just plow your way though 100‘s of pounds of rotting meat. This game is realistic when it come to violence and you must proceed with caution. Be very strategic about you go about killing these monsters if you do not have the right medical equipment on hand.

Personal Opinion This is a great game and will be getting more to play with friends! The great graphics and story line are amazing and cant wait to live the zombie struggle in co-op mode! It makes it a hundred times better that I can craft my own camp that I can share with my friends and store away items that I don’t need that moment. The fact that its a free roam add to that great feeling of abandonment and the only way to survive is craft eat and drink! This is one of those good wasteland survival games but with a whole different view and great compatibility with the users.

Final recommendation: I deffenetly recommend this game to others! This game is great to play with friends so you may destroy countless zombies together and achieve survival with your buddy! I rate this game 8.5 mainly because the menus are a little hard to control and not many options to optimize your game. Not a big fan of the birds eye view, which they did a fantastic job of doing by the way, but makes it a little...distracting at first. I did not find a lot of cons about this game. Overall it just mainly needs a user friendly interface to let the user get in and out of the menus easier and quicker.

Early Access Review

I like it!
I liked the first one, even though it was linear and a bit arcadey, the humor and story struck me to keep playing and the mechanics were fun. Since this sequel was on sale for 70% off, I figured what the hell and dove in to EA.

I think everything is markedly improved over the original. Progression in the game seems more balanced and well paced. It might be in EA, but it already feels very complete to me. Just needs some love and polish in some places. UI/Menus could be a little better, but they are functional.
Some people are having some problems getting the game to work properly for various reasons, but I myself have not run into anything that validating/verifying the game files didn't fix.

For anyone having played the first, the mechanics will be very familiar.
Eat or your melee damage will suffer when you begin to starve.
Drink or your vital critical hits will charge slower.
Basically, if you are starving or dehydrated you'll probably die from zombies before you actually starve to death, just because you won't be as effective in killing hordes.
I've never tested what happens when you get to 0%, though.

Crafting is key.
This game takes the crafting to the next level. Your camp level affects everything you do, as you can only level your character to your camp level. Item recipes are locked behind levels of buildings, which you will need to gather many supplies to upgrade, to finally build yourself some decent gear.
Makes everything you do feel like it pays off once you've made some decent kit for yourself.
Also visually rewarding having a little camp to go home to after quests to dump your loot at.
I've also noticed as I've built up buildings and walls, that zombies don't seem to spawn within my camp, which is good. It's a safe space.

You can replay any quest any time you feel like at varying difficulties.
Want to feel like a super bad-♥♥♥ zombie slayer? Knock the level of the quest down -2 and go zombie wrecking. Also good for quick supply runs.
Need a challenge? Ramp up the quest level +5 over your level. Serious XP gains if you manage to survive. (Each death is a -10% xp penalty)
I usually play at +3 for a nice 10% xp bonus with not too much added difficulty.

The game is funny.
I enjoy the little humour the game has and some of the quests are just the right amount of silly. It's one of the things that really charmed me in the first game and I'm glad they kept to it. There are enough try hard serious" zombie games out there

this one is just good fun.

TL;DR
Basically if you enjoy ARPGs
recommended: you'll probably enjoy How to Survive 2."

How to Survive 2 is a game where you fend off zombies while looking for supplies
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2o-ZsdPyfA
In the game's current state I can not recommend it. It is far from being a bad game, it just currently lacks any depth, and needs polishing.
You start off in a hub area, where you can select your next mission by talking to a character. After doing that, you will be transported to another small area where you are given a task. This is where the problems start with the game. Each mission feels the same. You walk around picking up random scattered items, or walk somewhere and complete the mission in 5-10 minutes. They feel like cheap fetch quests, and offer little variety.

This wouldn't be too bad if the gameplay was fun, but it gets repetitive. The combat consists of mashing the same button over and over again. It doesn't feel satisfying. You can also hold the attack button to do a charged attack, or sprint and then attack a zombie but all of these don't really add much. Using a ranged weapon like a bow is a bit different. You aim the weapon at a zombie and a circle will appear on their head. A line goes back and forth which requires that you press the button at the right time for what I'm assuming is more damage. I never really noticed a difference since it seemed to do the same amount of damage whether I got the timing right or not. Perhaps it's because I played on an easier difficulty.

Before starting a mission you can increase the difficulty which will also allow you to reap a higher xp reward.

The inventory/crafting/XP system has a lot of problems. First off, you can't create your character. You hit a randomize button and keep doing it until you like the look of your character. The crafting system looks ugly, although it works. My main gripe comes with the leveling up system. If you want to get a new skill, for example, do more damage, then you'll see a 500xp price tag on it. You spend the xp, and still won't level up that skill. That's because you need to level it up in 4 different chunks before actually getting the upgrade. Why? Why not just ask for 2000xp and level up the entire thing at once. It's not a big deal, but adds clutter the leveling system doesn't need. To add to that, in order to be able to upgrade your skill, you need to first upgrade your character, and in order to upgrade your character you need to upgrade your camp. It's a needlessly complicated system.

I personally dislike the PC controls. You can't rebind them, so I was forced to use controller controls as they felt a bit better. Even if you use PC controls, the inventory system will show xbox controls and require that you press R1" to navigate

Aside from that, I did notice some random online latency issues and game freezing for a few seconds at a time during solo and multi-player for no reason at all, nothing too serious, but minor optimizations wouldn't go un-noticed. Melee combat seems to have a memory, so spamming the attack button is definitely never a good idea as it locks you in place while you finish the melee attack combination leaving you vulnerable from the back or sides. So just make sure not to spam the buttons and it'll work just fine.

The difficulty curve is set up really nicely overall. During quests, you can make them as difficult as you want and be rewarded with more XP if you chose to make them more difficult. I really like how they did that. I also like the camp building process, though I do wish it was a bit easier to do. Graphics are nicer than the first How to Survive, though I have very little accuracy or aim ability while indoors, so that needs a bit of tuning in my opinion.

Overall, I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first How To Survive game. Sure I mentioned a lot more flaws than features in my review, as I do with most of my reviews, but you already knew what the features were when you read the game's description and watched the videos.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I loved the first game and How to Survive 2 is definately a nice addition to the series. However, after reading some of the over-enthusiastic reviews, I was also a bit disappointed.

Building your own camp is pretty cool and works great. Also the new city areas definately add to the fun, because indoors melee weapons are a much better choice than they ever were in HtS 1. But even outdoors melee is much more important now, because there is not that huge overflow of ammo from every second zombie you kill anymore. You will meet some familiar faces from the first game, which is pretty cool too. And the new types of zombies make things a little more interesting.

However, there were some things that I don't really like about HtS 2.
- The instance-based mission system may not be a turn-off for some people, but I really don't like it. You can accept missions in your camp and get teleported to the quest map to do your stuff and then return to the camp. HtS 1 had a much more open world-ish feel to it (it's not really open world but you can run around the islands all you want and don't get teleported somewhere else when you get a quest), which I liked better. Also, there are basically just 3 different types of missions: Kill X amount of zombies, collect Y amount of some resource or find person Z and talk to them.
- The level system is the worst part about this game though in my opinion. It is a very artificial limitation of progress and doesn't really fit into the game. You have to spend XP to level up your camp first, which does nothing except allow you to upgrade your buildings to the same level. Only after you have upgraded your camp can you level up yourself by spending XP, again changing absolutely nothing, except increasing your mission levels and allowing you to level your skills higher. You spend a large chunk of your XP on leveling up, which does absolutely nothing in itself, except making the zombies stronger (they level up with you or your camp depending on where you are). Meaning by leveling up, you don't become stronger, but actually weaker, because you don't gain anything but the zombies become stronger.
In HtS 1 at the beginning you just beat a few zombies up with a stick and at the end you killed massive hordes of zombies with the weapons you had earned by then, feeling absolutely godlike. In HtS 2 however, since the zombies level with you, the zombies are pretty much equally strong all the time, so you will face the same amount of them at any time pretty much all the time. This makes you feel like you are not really progressing that much after you get your first good gun or bow (whatever you prefer). All that changes is that higher damage-numbers pop up above the zombie heads when you hit them (yay ...).
- There are only very few types of different buildings in the city areas, making all maps feel pretty much the same. Sure this is still EA and I hope they will add more content. Just wanted to point that out.
- There are not enough missions to level up to max level, so you will have to start grinding missions you have already completed at some point. Again, this is EA and more will hopefully come.
- The story was MUCH better in HtS 1. Each NPC gives you some quests and they build up around some kind of storyline, but it's not really engaging and the different storylines aren't really connected all so much to each other. I'll wait what future quests add to the game.
- No boomerang :(

I don't mean to sound to negative, because this game is absolutely worth the money. I just think some people may like the more arcadey, story-driven, open world-ish HtS 1 more than this and could be a bit disappointed that HtS 2 is taking a somewhat different approach. As a final advice: Do play this with friends. It's just so much more fun that way. Gathering all the materials for your base can be a bit tedious when you have to get everything yourself.

Early Access Review

I got into HTS2 expecting it to be a pretty linnear story based game like the first one. While it IS very much a HTS game and feels like one, this one is rather different. First time I played there wasn't much to do and building/crafting was barely in place. But with later updates the game got a lot better paced. So overall a pleasant experience. So as a preliminary review I have some points.

Pros:
Base building.
Crafting is pretty simple, but more in-depth than many other games
Co-op is fun, and camp progression makes this work really well
You don't HAVE to follow others in a camp, but do your own thing
Graphics look pretty nice and fits the style of game, with varied weather and day/night cycle
Difficulty ramps up with progression
Pretty frequent updates, which each one seems to actually do quite a bit
Cons:
Melee combat feels really clunky. Being able to aim before hitting would be nice
The base building can be iffy at times, but seems to be better with each update
How you see through walls and floors indoors is weird, just hiding more/all of the walls would be better
No graphic settings or such.
Ranged aiming can bug out sometimes and now show the zombie being targeted
UI can be confusing, with separated menus and functions.
The camp progression can have you not focus on your own character skills, and to progress in missions you need camp level, meaning one could become rather weak and starve a lot due to wanting to do new missions. Not sure if separated exp for camp and combat would be good.
In overall, I really do like the game and playing it co-op lately, which I feel the game really is made for due to how the camps work. If you like survival games, games with crafting and building etc, you should get this. And do find people to play with.

Another small note, if you look at the negative reviews, they're mostly from the earlier stage of the game, where I do agree it didn't have much. But many of these negative reviews also stated the game likely would be a fun game later on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey Folks!  I thought I would pop on here and leave a review for this How to Survive 2.  I had this title given to me by a friend who thought given my love of Zombie titles that I would like it.  Even though I have owned the original for awhile I never actually got around to playing it.  As a result I was not exactly sure what to expect when I started playing it.

I wrote up an impressions piece on my own blog [aggronaut.com] but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.  That said the game is very much not finished, but because of that I can't really judge it any more harshly than any other Early Access title.  The price-tag of $20 seems extremely reasonable for the experience, and I have been using this as a game when I don't really have much time to play something deeper.  It allows me to get in, run a few missions... and feel like I have made some progress.

There is a nostalgic characteristic to the game that reminds me of the way it used to feel to explore maps in the original two fallout games.  For being a top down isometric game... it is strangely suspenseful anytime you explore an area with only the cone of your flashlight to see by.  There were several times I was surprised as zombies lumbered in from directions I was not quite expecting them.  At first the zombies are pretty brain dead, but as you level both your camp and your character... they start mixing in some of the modern track star zombies, and other types like boomers.

My biggest complaint right now is that there isn't much of a tutorial and I had to rely largely on copious amounts of googling to sort out how various aspects of the game actually work.  The game loaded fast enough that the keyboard screen was not up for long enough for me to memorize the various hotkeys...  and it was only by accident that I realized how to bring that menu back up.  That said... at this stage of the game no game really has a functional tutorial.  It is a game in progress, and so long as you are willing to play a beta product you should enjoy yourself.  If you cannot handle playing a non-finished game... then I would hold off until the official release.

Early access essentially gives players a way of getting access to a game right now... rather than waiting for it to be finished.  If you are not sold on the concept, then feel free to wait.  However I am having fun and continue to keep poking my head in every so often to see it progress.  My general stance on Early Access is to play extremely lightly until the game gets a little closer to release.  So long as you have all of these things in mind, I think its worth the $20 because the final launch will probably be significantly more.

Kovac is a fascinating character, and through exploring the 'camp' world, I've discovered that at least one character from the previous game, Kenji, made an appearance. I liked playing Kenji in the original, so it's great that I get to see him again in this game.

Also, I would like to see support for mods, so that players can add their own weapons, armor, and other things.

All in all, tl/dr, I give this game 8.5/10. Buggy, but fun.

I'll start with the bad/annoying things and get that out of the way.

- The leveling system is a bit daft, it's no longer just a case of leveling up just your character, you have to level up your camp, then level up your character THEN level up your skills after that. Ballache,
- The new aiming system needs picking up and throwing off the nearest cliff and be replaced with the one out of the first game. You go to shoot one walker and it's alright, you have 3 coming for you and you are buggered, might as well just bend over and prepare your ♥♥♥♥.

It's not all bad though, for something thats just (I could be wrong) come out of Alpha then bravo. Now the good,

- Building a camp. It's a really nice touch to the game and it works so far. With the first game it was just do missions and do some more then finish it. This adds a bit more for you to think about and do.
- Customise your character. Yay!
- Crafting. It plays a bigger roll and has more options than the first game already and this is just the early access.
- 4 player Co-op (When you can find someone to play with)
- Crossbows.

Overall the game so far plays well, there is room for improvement but it is to be expected from a game that is Early Access. So if you are looking for a near finished game then avoid this for now because you will end up disapointed and probably asking for a refund but if your like me and don't mind a few bugs here and there then I'd recommend this because if the first game is anything to go by then this will end up being bloody awesome.

Update -

Since I did this review the developers have been adding more and more into the game by the day and patched out anything bug related. It's a shame people have been giving this game bad reviews and marking it down because it's a EA release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was quite surprised by this game.
It has a lot of great things going for it and also a few minor issues here and there but no deal breakers.

Pros:
- Fun but challenging combat.
Awesome executions with melee and feel skilled with a bow and one shotting unsuspecting zombies. Also you have to be careful against stronger enemy types and large groups of zombies which adds to the excitement.
- Great crafting system.
You can make a lot of guns and armour but it doesn't give you them all at once, you have to progress and put XP into the right areas to do so.
- Good leveling system.
You can distribute XP into different areas and lets you adapt whatever playstyle/weapons you like. You can put all XP into character and base level and just make a base if you want but combat gets harder over time.
- Good balance between combat and building stuff.
Fight zombies to get supplies then make stuff to kill more zombies.
- Base building is awesome.
I loved making a camp in this game and it felt awesome to see it finished with guard towers, walls, weapons crafting area, armour crafting area and a cooking area. And later in the game you get traps which I'm looking forward to heaps!

Cons:
- Lacking in story a bit.
This game does have a story but the real interest in doing the missions comes from the item rewards rather than wanting to learn more about Kovac or help people. The story is alright but I found myself skipping dialogue a few times to get back to the combat and crafting.
- Difficult to find food unless in city/town area during a mission.
I would like it if there was a set mission to go on a supply run just to get food and drink, I found myself repeating other, older missions to do this instead and it gets a little boring.
- Various issues with online connectivity and screen resolution due to Beta. Understandable of course, but here are some of the issues I've had:
- My friend kept getting disconnected from me during game and became unplayable online for him.
- Screen resolution is square and game only plays in a windowed" mode.
- Lag issues and frame drops here and there but nothing major yet.


Overall I really like this game and it is unfinished so I don't mind all the small issues and I'm sure most of them will get fixed as the game is developed and comes out of Beta.

My Rating: 9/10

I would definately recommend this game and think it's really good value for money.

Also just a side note

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game which is always improving itself.
Before reading my review, please keep this in mind:
This is an EA title, which means this game is currently under development. It may have issues and problems which could interrupt the game progresses and make this game not that enjoyable. Therefore, think carefully before purchasing this game, always be patient and polite if you have encountered any trouble, and feel free to discuss about your troubles with others in the thread.

Playing How to Survive 1 before start playing How to Survive 2 is recommended.

How to Survive 2 was released on Oct 29th, 2015. After over 5 months of development, many major features and functions are already implemented.

Compared with How to Survive 1, How to Survive 2 is still having a long way to go. But just thinking about my experience in How to Survive 1, what devs may achieve in How to Survive 2, and what an amazing price for a good game like this, I cannot keep this game out of my door.

Although How to Survive 2 is still in Early Access phase, devs are experienced. They've dealt with many things in How to Survive 1, and I am sure that their capabilities and confidence were what brought them to this title. So personally I am thinking highly of the future of How to Survive 2.

Besides, devs and customer support are actively hearing from the community and are very willing to communicate with players on discussions, in order to make How to Survive 2 a more enjoyable game. So feel free to give feedback and suggestions about the game. And again, be patient, and be polite.

+Graphics and optimizations are good
+Sound effects are good
+You're able to build your own camp and develop it into a fortress together with your friends. Isn't that wonderful?
+Balanced skill progression system with depth
+Various weapons and armor sets, and modules to upgrade your weapons and armors
+Missions can be replayed with option of setting mission levels, which means stable and controllable source of materials and EXP

-Lack of voice acting for some NPCs
-Some important but not vital functions are not yet implemented, for example public camp searching tool, wells with clean water, beds so you can sleep and recover your mental status
-Need more options for character customizations (decorative/cosmetic items)
-Tutorial is not as detailed as it used to be in How to Survive 1 (which is why I suggest you guys to play How to Survive 1)

After all, I can say that How to Survive 2 is worth the $15 full price.

And yes, I give this game a thumb-up.

How to Survive 2 is an excellent title, and is preferable of those that are available, and here's why.

Start with a baseball bat, Smash some zombies' face in, then you start to find materials,  materials you can use to begin building a camp.

From you camp you build a variety of crafting stations from which you cook food, make weaponry from  bows to wooden firearms, work with metal and turns bits of lead into ammo, Take random junk you find and make armor, and take plants and rocks and make some gunpowder.

The beauty of this game is freedom. Sure, you need missions to gather food and whatnot, but as for your camp? You have a large woods area and can build your camp literally Anywhere. Want a tunnel to access Kovac more easily? Done. Wanna live out of a train car on abandoned tracks? done. wanna live in a ditch? Also done. You can build, create, and fight waves of zombies, and the beauty is you don't even have to stick to one spot. Bored with your camp? Build a new one!


As for zombies, welll...they're very....varied. There are different types of zombies, and as you progress in levels, more type will present themselves, and in greater numbers. FIrst, they walk...then jog...bows are fine for these, but whaat to do when they run at you, 10 at a time? Haha. Yes, zombies can run, you also have bloated ones that explode, deer, turkeys, pelicans, zombies that only come out at night, and run faster than anything.

As for a story, it's actually quite interesting. Exploring the woods your camp is set in provides an interesting backstory into the universe. Kovac, Survival enthusiast, assists you in beginning to survive. THe brothers, who live in the woods just away from kovacs tunnels, bicker back and forth, but reward you for your assistance. Kenji, from the first game, has burning hatred for Kovac and his fans, and wants your help in undermining them...and I imagine more will present themselves.

Now, remember, I'm not an isometric person, and I LOVE this game. So yeah, the viewpoint can be daunting for me, but the game itself is way worth it.

I am not too happy with the gun crafting system as the first game had a massive customisable feature. You had this bit, this bit and this bit... now depending on which of the next three changed the weapon. Or you replace the first bit and get a whole new set of options!
Now, it's all levelled hard-craft choices. build 'this item' with 'these stats' and deal with it.
Ammo is all bullets. Loud and attention-grabbing. so there's another step down.
Upgrading your gear should make killing enemies easier... not say 'hey, i killed one of you. all rush me!' so it seems to be forcing you back towards the bow and crossbow.
Melee weapons are much the same. Can't mess up 'hit them until they stay down'.

The buildings allow for great new recipies, but could do with the option to MOVE ONCE PLACED! My biggest complaint about the base-building is that once it's down, deal with it.
Put something down wrong? deal with it or destroy it.
Like many other things, once you've done it, it's stuck.
I feel that this game could do with some more features (like 'move buildings' or 'define camp area') and will gladly take back any of these comments if they're already on the drawing board and appear later.

I like the option to 'increase the difficulty' of missions. that's great for testing gear, grinding XP or keeping things interesting... but again, with hard-choice crafting, you don't get the customisability and have to carrry alternate options with you instead.

The inventory system is weight-based, no longer slot based (one of the better choices made) but with one glaring problem...
YOU NAVIGATE IT WITH A CURSOR!
With a mouse, that's perfectly fine and makes sense... with a controller (which is apparently the suggested method of play) a cursor is a nightmare to use!

Generally, I was far more impressed with the first game than this one.
Worth a play for fans of the genre (moreso if they havn't played the first) but I can't recomend this game to anyone full-price.

I'm probably going to be harsh on this game, but it seems to me like the core gameplay/mechanics are complete. I feel like the game tried to be a bit like Don't Starve. All the pieces are here for a really great game. Unfortunately, the execution leaves a lot to be desired.

Pros:
- Game is very stable.
- Crafting is not bad
- Combat is okay

Cons:
- Missions are awful. Exclusively fetch quests or Go here and kill/collect X things"
- AI isn't. Everything runs at you in a straight line. Some things are faster than others.
- Thirst and hunger are ultimately pointless.
- For a game called "How to Survive
date:
survival is surprisingly easy. I've found it really hard to die unless I crank the mission level to the max.
- Missions are meant to be repeated. Do a mission, collect resources, do it again.
- The game's key areas are swamps, forests, and an urban environment. Why there are so many zombies in the swamps and forests is a mystery, but ignoring that, the environments and textures are repeated ad nauseum. The environments aren't exciting to begin with, but are constantly re-used.

I'll keep my eye out for any significant updates, but I believe the game right now is a pretty good representation of what the finished product will be. It's not completely terrible, but... well, it's mostly terrible. Enjoy your swamps and forests.

So if there is more than 1 you just swing and hope you don't take a hit, run away a little bit, come back and swing again. They do little dmg, but still your guy shouldn't feel so vulnerable like a girl scout. Sometimes my guy does a long heavy swing when I don't want him to. This happens when I tap mouse 1 more than once sometimes when the actual way you have to do it is to hold it down and charge it up. It always makes me take a unnecessary hit from the enemy. You can't move when doing a heavy charge attack, which leaves you very vulnerable, so I just don't use it hardly at all.

The graphics even on ultra are really bad and even though I have way more than what this game requires including a gtx 970 with acx 2.0 dual fan cooling, and the game still makes it sound pretty loud. Louder than what it sounds while playing the Battleborn open beta (which really isn't loud at all) and almost as loud as it sounds when running The Division (which is loud). The first game looked pretty decent but this game just looks ugly as hell, every bit of it including effects.

Everything else is very bare and generic as well, including the UI, menu's, dialogue boxes, etc. It's just depressing gray or black boxes with no prompts either (I figured out spacebar was to continue dialogue).

I would be more than happy to give it a thumbs up when it gets more work. Since October of last year when it hit early access it should be further along by now, especially with blockbusters like Battleborn and Doom coming out May 3rd and 13th. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this because I enjoyed the first game but the gameplay and controls feel nothing like its predecessor. This review is of early access and I would not recommend getting this game yet as it is still not at a stage where it is an enjoyable experience.

Edit: I originally put this review up just for any friends that would stumble upon it, but I was requested to provide more detailed feedback.

As I mentioned the controls feel nothing like the previous game, notably when you charge up a melee attack you are stuck in one spot and you are no longer able to hold the attack longer nor release early.

In the previous game all the areas were interconnected which was more satisfying when exploring and revisiting the area again later would have map revealed. In this game the areas are temporary instances which can be replayed with random changes, which maybe be good for replay but they aren't connected to anything and there is really no reason to bother replaying.

The difficulty in this game scales up as you increase in level, unlike in the previous game where your  improvements help to make enemies easier, the increasing difficulty completely negates any advantages being of higher level if not making enemies more difficult to deal with.

It might be fun to play this game multiplayer, but this area is lacking. Multiplayer menus and searching are not intuitive and/or not existant, I am not really sure as I haven't worked it out.

Character creation or selection should be the first thing you do in the game. Starting with a generic character and having to find the customisation menu hidden away somewhere, I found that there wasn't any particular attachment to the character. In the previous game even with only 3 character to choose from, I seemed more invested in the character.

First of for those that have the first game how to survive will remmeber Kovak as being a crazy russian guy with a twisted sense of humor, this one he has no personality and the sense of humor is almost gone as if the survival has been to much for him, or it is a diferant person who designed him this time, this makes the game a little tad grey when talking to him.

When in playing the game now i can see that that vission i had is gone, in real its is a instanced game with very little freedom give to you as a player. Buy or Not - at this time i have got to say the game is worth the price tag for it but i wouldnt pay anymore for it, the game istelf is good for fist 4 - 8 hours after that its very repetative. So if your looking for a open world sandbox zombie survival game then this is not for you.

Nothing really too this game. Can't really imagine what group it's appealing too. The content (tut, map etc) was barebones and seemed like a game from the 2000's.  The gameplay (combat, surviving and 'camps') is *not* what is promised, or what it appears to be in the exaggerated screen shots. The combat is point and click, but you have to click exactly after each swing because the game isn't user friendly and doesn't 'queue' up attacks which makes it feel sluggish and bugged. Surviving just entails watching your food and water bar drop % and then right click pixels to fill it up... Yay, fun... The camps are just a glorified bank, that's it. It's also the only real place to dump all your resources into as well; making all that scavenging and looting utterly empty.

Sorry How To Survive team, but you should pack up shop and leave it to the innovative people. To continue this game would be to hire a group of people specialised in burrying their own franchise. I mean where is all their energy going??? Must be one hell of a chill job.
